objinfo.objsize: 25.7 x 43.5 cm. (including frame lines); 28.4 x 43.5 cm. (including inscriptions)

provenance.name: Society of Antiquaries, London
provenance.note: The Society of Antiquaries commissioned Blake's engraving master, James Basire, to execute this drawing for publication as an engraving in Joseph Ayloffe, *An Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey*, 1780. Basire assigned Blake to this task. The drawing was presumably delivered to the Society shortly after its execution.

objnote.p: The image includes a horizontal scale in feet, numbered 1 through 18. The writer of the inscriptions is not known.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The composition depicts the tomb monument to Anne of Cleves in Westminster Abbey. The monument has three main components, all of which sit on a narrow, low platform. The three sections are of equal height, appear to be made of stone, and have undecorated, flat tops. A long, rectangular central structure is flanked by two narrower structures at right and left. The side of the central structure facing the viewer is divided into rectangular panels and intricately decorated. Two vertical panels on the right and left ends of the structure protrude slightly outward and span the monument's height. The left panel includes a central circle with the initials "AC" for Anne of Cleves. The insignia is topped by a crown with three visible trefoils. Additional vegetative and other motifs decorate the panel. The rightmost panel also contains a central circle topped by a crown surrounded by vegetative and other decorative motifs. Inside the circle here is a eight-pointed star or compass. The central section of the monument is divided into two horizontal sections with three large panels in each. The three panels in the upper section are undecorated; however, the four smaller spaces separating them are filled with vegetative or other abstract motifs. The three panels in the lower section each contain a skull and crossbones as well as a winding ribbon. The central skull faces forward while the skull at left faces right and the skill at right faces left. Four tall, slender vases, each with different decorations, are visible in the spaces separating these lower panels. The monument's narrower structures at left and right have identical decorations on the side facing the viewer: a central oval encircling the head of a lion with an open mouth surrounded above and below by vegetative or other decorative motifs. On both structures, a second decorative panel is visible on the side facing the longer middle structure; however, the details of this design are indistinguishable. Triangular areas of shadow are visible on the monument's supporting platform to the left of both the left most structure and the central structure. A scale measuring eighteen feet is visible near the bottom edge of the composition.

component.illusobjdesc: The composition depicts the tomb monument to Anne of Cleves in Westminster Abbey. The monument has three main components, all of which sit on a narrow, low platform. The three sections are of equal height, appear to be made of stone, and have undecorated, flat tops.

A long, rectangular central structure is flanked by two narrower structures at right and left. The side of the central structure facing the viewer is divided into rectangular panels and intricately decorated. Two vertical panels on the right and left ends of the structure protrude slightly outward and span the monument's height. The left panel includes a central circle with the initials "AC" for Anne of Cleves. The insignia is topped by a crown with three visible trefoils. Additional vegetative and other motifs decorate the panel. The rightmost panel also contains a central circle topped by a crown surrounded by vegetative and other decorative motifs. Inside the circle here is a eight-pointed star or compass. The central section of the monument is divided into two horizontal sections with three large panels in each. The three panels in the upper section are undecorated; however, the four smaller spaces separating them are filled with vegetative or other abstract motifs. The three panels in the lower section each contain a skull and crossbones as well as a winding ribbon. The central skull faces forward while the skull at left faces right and the skill at right faces left. Four tall, slender vases, each with different decorations, are visible in the spaces separating these lower panels.

The monument's narrower structures at left and right have identical decorations on the side facing the viewer: a central oval encircling the head of a lion with an open mouth surrounded above and below by vegetative or other decorative motifs. On both structures, a second decorative panel is visible on the side facing the longer middle structure; however, the details of this design are indistinguishable.
Many of the decorative panels on the three structures of this monument contain representations of vegetation, including vines, leaves, and other indeterminate forms.

Triangular areas of shadow are visible on the monument's supporting platform to the left of both the left most structure and the central structure. A scale measuring eighteen feet is visible near the bottom edge of the composition.

lg.l: The Monument of Anne of Cleves, fourth wife of King Henry VIII, on the South side of the Altar in Westminster Abbey. Vide Velurt. Mon. Vol. II. Plate XXXV.
